reviewText:
Tales of Symphonia is a fantastic game as I'm sure anyone would tell you after they've played the GC original or even the PS3 port.  If you haven't played it yet either as a fan of the series or as someone interested in getting into the series, there is no other game I would recommend over Symphonia as a starting point.  It's not the best in the series but it's still one of the most solid entries and should be experienced if only because this game is ultimately what popularized the series in the west.

However...

Bamco continues to not care enough about their consumers to put any kind of effort into making a proper PC port.  Lacking features that should be standard this day and age appropriate with the times for 2016 PC gaming.  Several errors that cause the game to not even run at all on some systems.  Not even indie developers tend to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up like this.  What's so mysterious about this completely poor showing is that it's hard to say they're just pushing out a quick and dirty port and having the name alone carry them to profits when it takes the fans literal MINUTES to fix a lot of the problems.  Surely it's not an issue of allocating their resources at Bamco.

No, instead we have framerate limiters and upscaled 720p alongside 'anti-piracy' measures that prevent the fans from removing some of these issues for a game that can still be pirated AND emulated better years ago in its GC incarnation.  It's not a matter of them being lazy and doing what should be an extremely simple task to bring their game to a modern PC audience, they are ACTIVELY NEUTERING THEIR GAME instead for who the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• knows why.  They don't have to 'fix' the game so much as they have to just remove restrictions that they themselves put in place.  Try figuring that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out.

Don't give them your money.  These ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s are literally toying with you to see what they can get away with and still get your money for.  Pirate the GC version because it'll perform a lot better.  If we continue to support amateur hour work like this, we are going to continue to get amateur hour work like this.  The only language big businesses know is the one your wallet speaks.  Don't be part of the problem.

reviewText:
Leaving a bad review for this title makes me quite sad, as Tales of Symphonia was one of my top five games when I was younger.
The worst part is, the game itself (probably) still holds up fantastically....it's just that the people that handled the port, they have the sense of a drunken cliff diver, when it comes to PC ports.
I should have stuck to my resolution to NOT buy any Koei Tecmo or Namco Bandai PC ports. *sigh*

-The game is locked to 30FPS (and often drops down below that on a 3770k and 7970). That is considering that it ran at a consistent 60FPS on the Gamecube over a decade ago.
-Being upscaled, everything is variable levels of blurry. The cutscenes look like someone smeared vaseline all over the screen. Also, the character models are higher fidelity than environments, so they look entirely out of place in the environments.
-The animations of characters (including just running around on the overworld) feel weirdly twitchy and unresponsive. I wonder if it has to do with the framerate.
-As usual fare from this company, you have unnecessarily invasive and intrusive DRM. Guys, do you want people to buy your product or to nick it? This isn't helping and it only encourages the latter, as people don't want to pay for a bad experience if they can have a far better one for free. I thought we learned this lesson from this music industry and all the idiotic tat that Ubisoft was doing?
-The game also seems to be oddly unstable. I've had CTDs when launching the game, I've had CTDs when trying to toggle things in the Options menu, I've even had a CTD when I simply left Lloyd standing idle.
-Alt+Tabbing locks the game for some 30+ seconds.
-No mouse support anywhere. Did you forget that you were porting this to PC?
-I know this might sound petty, but... Why are there only six save slots? I haven't had my Gamecube in years, but I'm pretty sure even the GC version wasn't that limited.

At this point, I'm going to wait a bit and see what patches the developer will release and, if they are inadequate, I will refund the game. I hope that we get the title back at some point in a better state (and, preferably, without the invasive DRM), but... You know what they say. Hope into one hand, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• into the other, and see which one fills up first.

The official release of this port was a real mess.
Thankfully, Bamco took the whole thing to heart and pretty much fixed all of the issues that plagued this game.
As it is now, there's no slowdown, no graphical hiccups, no more VMPROTECT and it works like charm on my Windows 7.
The only major quarrels about it would be the 30 FPS compared to the Gamecube version (But considering this is a port of the PS3 HD version, which was locked on 30 FPS, there's little point in complaining about that) and the fact that using directional arrows on the keyboard to move the character during block puzzles will prevent them from pushing or pulling the blocks, (Still, you can simply change the button config when that happens IF you're using a keyboard).
As it is now, the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable in all of its beauty, and I'm glad I was patient enough to have it in working order on my PC after loving it on the Gamecube!

reviewText:
I want to say that I have fond memories of Tales of Symphonia. I played the Gamecube version multiple times; it was an solid game that mixed up the staleness of the JRPG genre with some interesting mechanics. I would strongly recommend the game to anyone looking for some classics because, despite its worn visuals and flawed (PAINFULLY flawed, at times) voice-acting -- it's a powerful experience.

But I will not recommend this port. This is NOT a good port.

Starting up this decade-old relic of a game, one must avoid clicking away from the first (1st) window to pop up because doing so runs the risk of causing the entire game to crash. It does NOT like being tabbed out of. One would, however, be forgiven during this initial period for thinking that the game has completely crashed, because the load-up at times can take at least half a minute before you even get to the first Bandai-Namco splash. When you DO get to the main menu, be advised: attempting to enter the Customize" menu at the start menu (as well as from within a loaded game) causes the game to lock up for as much as 10 seconds at a time before bringing up the proper menu. The same is true of either saving or loading as well. And I cannot for the life of me understand the nonsensical decision to shove what few graphics options they allow at the very bottom of the options menu; your choices are limited to FULLSCREEN OR WINDOWED

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game. I bought it back when it was new on GameCube and loved the blend of smooth action combat, surprisingly detailed environment, engaging and sometime dark storyline, and that wonderful soundtrack. It's showing its age, but it's still very playable and a lot more approachable than Tales of Zestiria.

BAMCO had the opportunity here to release the definitive version of this game for GameCube and PS3 players alike. Instead we have this absolutely shocking port. Visual polish present in the GCN version back in 2004 is missing from this version, including heat haze effects and 60fps combat and town gameplay. The port appears to be based off the PS3 version which was also 30fps, but lacks the latter's fully voiced skits.

It's impossible to recommend this game in its current state. Stuttery 30fps lock, long load times, crashes and obnoxious DRM that prevents you from applying per-executable graphics settings are just the beginnings of this story. Kaldaien's patch fixes a lot of these issues, but that's not really something we should be having to mess around with. If you've already bought this game, check the forums for TSFix and you'll have a much better time.

Look, I wish i could say so much better things about this. You see, Tales of Symphonia is my absolute favourite game. I have 400+ hours on the gamecube alone of sheer fun and happiness from it. I am begging, sitting, waiting, hoping and praying for a patch, because it pains me very much to not recommend the game i love the most in my 20 year gaming career. So yeah, if you're thinking of buying this, don't do so yet. Wait for some fixes, it's basically unplayable as it currently is, though it pains me to say so.

reviewText:
Having played the Gamecube version at least 10 times and the PS3 version at least another 3, I think I'm more than qualififed to fairly judge what is a classic, gem in the 'Tales of' series.

The story of Symphonia may seem a bit cheesy and the characters a little cliched, but the truth is the story is really interesting and delves into the depths of racism, segregation, religion, guilt and fate. These topics get explored with a fantasy view-point but are still full of meaning and impact. The story keeps going strong, with twists and turns throughout and is also VERY long - a solid 30-40 hours easily without spending the time to do everything, such as side-quests. The New Game+ system works well and helps make replaying easier and fun, something you will want to do.

The gameplay itself is a little dated compared to modern Tales games, battles don't feel as fluid and the controls a bit sluggish, there is some depth to combat but its a lot simpler than say Xillia's link system or Zestiria's Seraph system, but it is still fun and certianly passable. Exporing and puzzle sovling is never amazingly intricate but is still quite fun. To be honest, most of the modern Tales games have lacked puzzles in their dungeons entirely so its a nice change in Symphonia that they at least attempted it. There are also many sidequests and a few mini-games that aren't too bad - plenty of content to go around.

All in all, Symphonia is a classic JRPG gem that is also a reflection of the time it came out (2003). A bit dated in performance and Gameplay but with a amazing story and loveable cast of characters you will want to come back.

---------
PC PORT SPECIFIC
---------
The PC port itself is somewhat a shoddy mess, however, as time is going on it is being fixed by Namco and, most importantly, modders. Thanks to Kaldaein's simple and easy to use TSFix and the removal of VMProtect, the game runs well and is perfectly playable, perhaps making it the best version of the game out there... excluding 60fps, but it s not the end of the world.

reviewText:
Upon release of the game, there were far too many issues that anyone would notice almost immediately. Stutters in frames, menu taking ages to open, unable to tab out and tab back in (would take from 30 seconds to two minutes to get back in), several graphical errors, and many typos that should not be there. It was literally a port of the first release that the PS3 had.

The game is fantastic itself, and is very worth your time to play it, but Dolphin emulator runs the Gamecube version better...

Recently, the patches have fixed a lot of loading time issues, but there are still frame rate stutters, random graphical glitches, and the occassional crash.

Recommend to play? YES! Play this incredible fantastic game, it's beyond well made for a JRPG, and should be enjoyed by everyone, whether they prefer gameplay or story.

Recommend to buy? Not just yet. Even though it is just $20 for a port of an old and fantastic game, there are still quite a few issues that need to be thoroughly addressed by Bandai Namco.

P.S. The game does NOT run at 60fps, it runs at 30fps (and yes it still stutters). But there's hope: Modding communities have banded together and are working almost non-stop on getting it to 60fps. Look into it if you're REALLY THAT OBSESSED over getting an extra 30fps in a game that is beautiful without it.

Some people have the solution of disabling firewall.  Well I live in China so disabling my firewall is like romping through a brothel without a condom.  No thanks.  I'll change my recommendation when they fix the damn game.

reviewText:
Among innumerable other issues, this game was shipped with 3 crippling limitations:
1) VMProtect implementation (FIXED via removal in the latest official path). This intrusive anti-tamperware forced the game to run in a virtual machine, massively slowing down startup times and making unnecessary, constant writes to your disk drive. It also briefly prevented modders from working to fix the issues detailed below.
2) Locked internal resolution of 720p.
3) Locked framerate of 30 FPS.

Namco has yet to do anything about the latter two issues. However, the locked resolution has been resolved by modders in addition to the numerous other improvements they have made. The frame rate, sadly, has yet to see a fix. I'd recommend waiting to buy this until it's genuinely the best version of the game to play, which IMO it won't be until the frame rate limiter has been overcome by the modders, which appears unlikely given the difficulties they have encountered, or patched out by the devs via a miracle.

Oh, and of course, shame to the devs for releasing a port in this state, yadda yadda, they don't care, etc.

reviewText:
Full review here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=95obbRs4TqQ

Y'know, I had high hopes for Symphonia's PC release after seeing how good of a PC port Zestiria was. Boy was I mistaken. The thing is, it isn't inherently the game that is the problem here, it's the PC port and it's such a massive let down to see how lazy Bandai have been with porting it. As someone who is a big fan of the franchise, I can't help but be dissapointed with how awful it turned out. I think it's best we start with the biggest issue and that is the state of the PC port, because it's bloody awful.

First things first, the frame rate is locked to 30FPS with no way to increase it. Some have managed to it get it to 40FPS but don't hold out hope for it to run at 60FPS. It's rather amusing really that a console which is more then 10 years old (The Gamecube) can run this game better then modern day powerful PC's and have the game run at 60FPS.

The resoltuion is also locked to 720p even though the game gives you the option to have it go up to 1920x1080. Putting it in 1920x1080 doesn't increase it to 1080p at all, it stays at 720p with no way to increase it without help from Durante which I'd like to point out, managed to break past the resolution lock in 14 minutes and raise the it to 4K. Yes, Durante is currently working on a fix for the game but it is starting to get to the point where we have to rely on a single person to fix something an entire company of people couldn't be bothered to do and becuase of that, they should ashamed of themselves.

There is also hidden DRM built into the game called VMProtect which creates a new *.exe file everytime you run the game which continues to baffle me still as to why that is there.

It's hard to think of all the things they messed up in this broken PC port, how about the localization? Yep, they messed that up also with differentl languages being completely broken, hell, even the english is broken with words being mispelled.

But the one thing they messed up the most, the biggest thing which I personally couldn't believe until I saw it for myself is the steam badges. They even got the steam badges wrong, which is completely unforgivable. I think that is what ruins this PC port on every level. Let's also not forget about all the crashes that stop people from down right playing the thing.

As far as PC ports go, this is by far one of the most insulting ones I've seen in a long time. They seemed to show absolutly no interest in the port which in turn, made the game worse for it and has led to a lot of unhappy customers.

The thing is, I would have loved to recommend this game, I really wanted to, but I can't with how terrible the PC port is and that hurts coming from someone who grew up playing this game 12 years ago (Did I mention this game is 12 years old?). It's unbelievable that we still have to deal with awful PC ports such as this and expect to like it or wait for someone who cares about the PC community to bring out a fix FOR FREE when an entire company who's job it is to fix this, y'know, the companies we give hundreds to every year, can't be bothered to do anything about it.

That's it, I can't recommend this as the PC port is just so awful which hurts such a great game, because behind it all, Symphonia is a great game that could've been brought to a much larger audience and introduced the series to more people as one of the best Tales Of games. Unfortunately, seemed that Bandai couldn't care less and for that, they can go felate a bee hive for all I care.

reviewText:
*UPDATED 2/29/2016*

Please note I will change my review if anything changes/updates to fix the current issues. I have played and beat ToS several times on the original Gamecube.

Tales of Symphonia is a JRPG where Lloyd and his friends venture off to regenerate the world. This is necessary to replenish the mana to the world so that it will prosper once again. Along the way some very interesting twists and turns happen that keep the story interesting and keeps you invested in it.

The battle system is very fun as it is played in real time. You control one of the four characters on the battlefield while the AI (or a couch co-op buddy) takes control of the others. You move in a straight line twords and away from the enemy and you can jump over enemies to attack them from behind. You have your basic attack and technical attack and how you attack is determined by how you tilt the control stick and your choice between the two. New technical attacks are learned as you fight and what types of attacks are learned are determined by how you fight. You can trigger full party unison attacks as well as special character attacks that deal a lot of damage. While this system is nothing fancy it still has a bit of depth to keep you wanting more.

All in all Tales of Symphonia is a fantastic RPG to start at or just play as I find it has everything that an RPG enthusiast would find fun. The only thing is though that the port quality is pretty bad.

Unfortunately though I cannot recommend the PC/Steam version of the game. As this port is nothing but a straight port of the PS3 version. Absolutely no work was put into it.

Basically since this is a ps3 port it runs at 30fps when the original version on the gamecube ran at 60fps except on the world map. Personally this doesn't bother me much but it does take some getting use to.

Next the game only renders at 720p meaning that if you raise the resolution to 1080p you will still see plenty of jaggies and blurry textures because the game is upscaling that 720p to whatever resolution you set it to.

One major problem that Bandai Namco fixed however was the removal of the Anti-Tamer software known as VMProtect. It did nothing but cause problems for many users because of how it works, but it was removed in a patch.

All in all if you can get past the technical issues in this barest of bones port the game runs fairly well and is the exact same Tales of Symphonia that we all know and love minus the 60 fps. It is still a really good and fun RPG to play, I just wish that Bandai Namco added basic PC functionality to the game. Like rendering the game at the actual resolution and some basic graphic options such as anti-aliasing, shadow quality, texture quality and such.

In the end though I cannot recommend this game as nothing was done to make it any better than the PS3 port, and that it lacks anything that would make it a good port. It could have been the definitive version of the game but Bandai Namco didn't even try.

The good news is that modders are working on the game to make it better. I just wish that we wouldn't have to resort to modders to fix a bad port.

TL:DR - if you can look past the technical issues of the game it is still very fun to play. I just wish that Bandai Namco put a little more effort into the port.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Disclosure, this game came free with my purchase of Tales of Zestiria last year.

With the unofficial fix Tales of Symphonia is a great game. If you are looking for 60fps then this game will probably never receive it. If you are only interested in 60 fps or greater then go with the GC version. The PC version has all the content from the PS2/3 release with it being graphically superior compared to the GC with the HD textures and the PS2/3 version.

This is with the fix however. If you don't use the fix it runs at 720p and the game stutters.

As for the actual game itself.

The battle mechanics definitely show their age. I wouldn't call them bad but you can tell that this was an early attempt into shifting to a 3D plane.

The story is one of the best in the series with enjoyable characters to boot.

If you use the english voices then you will note that some voiced sections have some character not actually speaking, this is because this game is based on the PS2 port which was Japanese only which added certain things to the game. If you switch the audio over to Japanese these sections are voiced.  The voice acting for the english side of it is a mixed bag and if you switch over to the Japanese side an important note is that one of your party members has a very obvious name change. Raine -> Refill („É™„Éï„Ç£„É´ literally Rifiru).

The start of the game having played it again is kind of on a slow boil but it starts picking up 6 hours in. Again having replayed this game sometimes the objective might come off cryptic to some people. The main objective of regenerating the world comes to mind. While this is what you need to do the game doesn't flat out tell you where you need to go. While I never had any trouble with this, having seen some of my relatives play this game and ask, where do I go next?" is something that I thought might be note worthy.

There are only 2 dungeons in this game that I would classify as tedious with one more that could be considered. Which are  the sewers
recommended: and shadow temple with the Shadow Temple and the sewers being what I considered tedious.\n\nOverall I would recommend this game."

reviewText:
Disregarding the unforgivable technical issues, some which still perseveres post-patch-update, and how it still manages to look even more awful than the original Gamecube version (Zeus bless that console's soul) Tales of Symphonia has honestly showed its age in its overall design. If you've already played the later entries like Vesperia, Xillia or even that terrible Graces F then you'll probably find yourself at a disadvantage with the combat--That of which Tales usually excels at isn't that good. I personally also find the lack of voice acting for the skits to be distracting quite a bit, given voice acting exists pretty much everywhere else in the game--Sure, the game is old but so is Final Fantasy X and it had plenty of voice acting--But getting into the voice acting, I'd dare say that isn't up to standards either which only serves to highlight the game's inexorable ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-dribling old age. I suppose not all old games could carry themselves quite as well  in terms of voice direction as Metal Gear, ironic given the narration is being done by Liquid Snake (Cam Clarke) but I digress.

In a world where an excellent port of a great JRPG like Valkyria Chronicles exist, Symphonia plays the role of the dog poo located next to a firmly build brick-house. You'd be much better off playing that or getting the PS3 Remaster of Symphonia and then get an addiotional game in the package as well.
Tales of Symphonia might be a really good game, but I dare say its age is showing and awful messy port-job does little to help justify, even warrant, it worthy as a good purchase.

reviewText:
(UPDATED 3/31/16) Yes, it runs. It's mostly the same great game from 15 years ago. It's even playable, in English. Co-op is still included, even if the Steam page doesn't mention it. But at this point I'm not going to recommend it.

The problem is that this is a straight PS3 port - anything that was wrong with that version is still wrong in this version - new stuff (and even some old stuff!) being translated oddly or just plain wrong, 30FPS lock from the PS2 version, etc. There are no PC-specific graphics options, and the game will render at a 720p resolution regardless of what you set your resolution to; on top of that it seems some sort of extra blur was added. Additionally, the framerate limiter makes it hard to consistently hit 30FPS on good (modern) hardware. It's been over a month since the last patch (which mostly served to remove the useless DRM limiting outside modifications, probably a sign of the devs throwing in the towel), so the odds of these being officially fixed are next to none.

It's certainly better now than it was at launch, but it's be ridiculously hard for them to make it worse. The fact that any mention of multiplayer was scrubbed from the Steam page implies that most of the game wasn't even tested before being sold.

The bottom line: It's a great game, but a terrible port. I can't recommend it at $20 until it's actually had $20 of effort put into it; if I'm expected to pay as much as a competent port of a similarly-aged game, I expect to get a competent port. I'll be more than happy to update my review if or when any of these issues are addressed. In the meantime, buy the PS3 version of Tales of Symphonia Chronicles - it's the same price, it consistently works the way it's supposed to, and includes the (admittedly disappointing) sequel.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this.  I LOVED the game on Gamecube, it was hundreds of fun hours.  But this is a really shoddy port.

Pros
+It's got the PS3 bonus content.
+It runs.  For most people.
+It's got a Japanese voice option, which is a nice touch.

Cons
-Internal resolution is locked to 720p.  You can set your output resolution to whatever you want, but the game will still internally render at 720p, with all the blurriness and jagginess that implies.
-DRM.  I've recently heard they use additional DRM beyond Steam, someone I read on neogaf was claiming it recreates the .exe file every time you start the game...?!  Regardless of what it does specifically, you have to recognize the insanity of putting DRM on a minimal-effort port of a game that's been out on PS3 for years, and with an easily emulatable GCN version--all DRM like this does is potentially punish legitimate users like me and you, while the people that illegitimately downloaded the game did so and probably finished it YEARS ago.  Those pirates?  I doubt they'll be wanting this version--that's how little this adds in terms of quality to the experience we've already had for years.
-More typos than ever?  The PS3 version didn't have a great localization, there were typos here and there, but this one takes the cake.  Battle Contorols
date: missing quotation marks, and more, all in the first five minutes of my playtime today.\n-Limited to 6 save slots in the save menu apparently?

reviewText:
Product received for free

Best described as the FF7 of its series, ToS is the one that helped the franchise really breakout in the west. I owned a GameCube, but ultimately decided the console wasn't worth constantly plugging and unplugging and let it gather dust because PS2, so I passed up on this title. Over ten years later, I ended up preordering Zestiria to get the bonus Symphonia and see what the fuss was about.

ToS launched in a deplorable state. Bamco launched the highly anticipated port of one of their most beloved titles as an unstable, buggy mess, which I'm pretty sure violates several Dwarven Vows. Months later, they finally updated it into a workable, playable game that doesn't require a fan-made mod to not be awful (but still helps).

The story initially revolves around a trio of friends: a swordsman named Lloyd, a tolerable child mage named Genis, and Colette, the Chosen of Mana". The mercenary Kratos and their teacher

One button allows you to use standard attacks while another uses one of four assigned special attacks depending on whether or not you use it with a directional button. The result is a fast and fun system that allows and rewards combos. The characters you don't control can have their AI customized and specific attacks disabled. Stat growth can also be influenced by assigning "titles"

reviewText:
Addicting RPG.
Small flaws, the english voice acting isn't great. But that is common with RPGs.
The overworld has odd camera angles that tend to irritate the hell out of you at times if you are used to the far back view that allows you to navigate easier/see the entire landscape before traveling. It forces you to venture more, which isn't horrible just something I personally am not accustomed to.

But the small action RPG battle mechanic keeps me thoroughly entertained, and it never seemed broken. The anime style cutscenes has a spot in my heart. The story though a bit general, kept me interested enough to never feel bored.

I don't know if this was a poor port fixed with time, but in my opinion the Mixed reviews isn't deserved. I used a controller, and never had any problem. With the type of combat system it is a bit expected for it to be easier with a controller over a keyboard especially as a port.

This is a good RPG, that RPG fans should check out. I think they will be surprised by how enterained they are especially for the overall review rating at this time.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review for one of my favorite games ever. I own the game on every possible device it has been released on. I own the GC, PS2, PS3 and now the PC version of the game and have poured probably thousands of hours into this title. You would think that as the time passes and technology progresses that these old games would only get better when they are remade for newer console. But that's not the case with Tales of Symphonia. To put it shortly the PC version is just one ugly mess.

Pros:
- Dual audio
- PS2 version extra content, few skins and bunch added hi-ougis (or mystic artes as they like to call them)

Cons:
- Locked 30 FPS even if the very first version on the Gamecube was solid and smooth 60 FPS
- Capped internal resolution of 720p (the year is 2016 btw and this is PC we are talking about)
- Crashes at startup, crashes when trying to access the customize menu, crashes alt+tabbing, crashes whenever it feels like
- Horrible translation errors in coding, letters missing or generally completely bugged menus
- Some kind of VMProtect to act as an additional DRM (yay) which changes the running .exe name and prevents stuff form Nvidia cp AND makes it even harder for modders to fix the damn game
- No support for mouse and keyboard

I would NOT recommend this version of the game to anyone. It's just a shameless act from Namco and no one should give them money for this kind of blatant robbery. I love the game itself, I really do. As I mentioned in the beginning I have it for every system and if you truly want the DEFINITE version of the game then the original Gamecube version if the way to go. It does lack a tiny amount of content (not a big deal, few skins and few mystic artes), but it's simply the most solid and smoothest experience of the game. Dolphin with the grapchical enhancements has been the most wonderful experience I've had with this game.

tl;dr: The game itself is one of the best games I've ever played, but the PC port is one of the worst ports I've ever played. DO NOT BUY!

~Refunding the game ASAP

reviewText:
EDIT: Since writing this review, the game has changed significantly for the better. Bandai-Namco has released several patches that fix a lot of the localization errors and button prompts, as well as removed the invasive anti-tamper software. In addition, if you use Kaldaien's TSfix mod (found in the guides for this game) then the game is definitively the best version of the game. Resolution errors are fixed, load times are reduced, borderless window support, it's great. The only nitpick that still exists in the game at that point would be the 30 fps lock. However, it's still enjoyable at that point.

That being said, I can now confidantly change my review to positive with the caveat that you go and download Kaldaien's TSfix.


Old review:

An absolute train wreck of a release. Aside a myriad of technical issues, the game doesn't even improve upon the 13 year old GC version. There are no graphics options of any kind and it is not recommended that you play on any resolution aside from the starting 1280x720. Otherwise you will see stretching, tearing, and aliasing. The game is locked at 30 fps instead of the 60 seen on the GameCube version, which feels extremely sluggish when the two are compared.

And to put the cherry atop it all: there are translation and grammar errors as soon as the main menu.

I love Tales of Symphonia. It's probably my favorite in the series. But I must caution you away from this port. It is not worth $20 until it is fixed. If you want to play ToS on PC then getting an emulator for the original GC version is your best bet. Worse than being a poor port the PC version of the game is inferior to the GC version in nearly every way and is a technical mess.

reviewText:
This game is as good as I remember it, and that means VERY good.

The best thing about cartoonish graphics like this game has, is that they never get old (some people complain about its frame rate and resolution, but instead of fussing about it, I'd solve it with currently existing fixes).

The gameplay is still fantastic, it has a relatively complex skill system that allows you to plan your own fight strategies. I find the Normal difficulty on the right spot, but it has two higher difficulty levels if you desire to make it more challenging, which is great for replays. Yes, another strong point of the game, is its replayability.

The sound isn't that special. Some catchy tunes, but that's it. It is voiced in the right moments with good english voices, though they rarely synchronize with the speaking mouths. It doesn't bother me, but it could be worth noting.

The story isn't very complex in the beginning, but later it gets more interesting, when everything starts trying to make sense. Every character has their own dramatic backstory, that makes their personalities very different to each other.

If I had to give it a score, I'd say 8.5 out of 10. I definitely recommend it, specially if it's on sales.

reviewText:
I'm already familiar with Tales of Symphonia (it's a great game) so I'm basing my review on the PC port rather than just the game; that seems to be the trend here.

After reading so many reviews, I was surprised that my eyes didn't explode in my head because of a locked 30 fps.  In fact I think the game looks great.  Sure it could look better but who cares,  Anytime there's glowing reviews of a retro pixel game, it's pretty much unanimously agreed upon that graphics aren't important - it's gameplay and/or story that matters - but as soon as a game is locked at 30 fps everyone is outraged.

I realize that I'm reviewing this game after several patches, and I know that upon the games release, it was kind of a mess, and I know that the original GameCube version looked better, but I don't care.  As it is now, I think the game looks and runs great and I have no complaints.

As of this writing, I've only put a half hour into the game, mainly to see how it looked, so there may be plenty of bugs and glitches ahead.  If that's true I'll change my review, but I wanted to add my two cents to the uproar about how the game looks.

In short, I think the game looks good and don't feel that that should be a hinderance in anyone's decision to buy it.  And I know from past playthroughs that the game itself is great.

I played this on the GameCube in its 60 fps glory.  I share the disappointment of it being locked to 30 fps so it's a little difficult to play it that way after playing the GameCube version.  But there are many other factors in making a game great and 60 fps is just one of them.

The story is good and it starts to run out of steam near the end but what JRPG storyline doesn't run out of steam at some point in the game?  The story alone was good enough for me.  The graphics look good for a HD remake of a GC game but dude, if I could play in 60 fps with 480p graphics, I would do that.  I believe a mod will eventually fix that framerate issue much to the joy of everyone.

I would still recommend this game but just barely.  If the 60 fps mode arrives, I'd strongly recommend it.  It's just a little difficult to play the game in 30 fps after playing it in 60 fps but it's still worth it.

reviewText:
For the sake of those coming to the reviews wondering if this port of a classic game, one of the best JRPGs of all time, is worth spending 20 dollars on, I can answer succinctly. The answer is not just 'No', with a capital N, but 'HELL NO', in all caps.

If you would like further edification, I will simply post below what I wrote when I requested my refund. But if you need no further information, then I cannot emphasize enough that this game SHOULD NOT BE PURCHASED.

-----

I'm choosing this option ('My issue isn't listed') because this port has too many various, unforgivably terrible issues. It's a game that originally ran on the Nintendo Gamecube at 60 fps, which is now locked at 720p + 30fps. It had numerous crashes and no mouse/keyboard support on launch. These are issues that will likely be fixed in the future but should have been fixed before the game was ever launched.

This is my favorite game from my childhood, and seeing it reduced to this state when I was hoping to relive that experience with at least moderately updated visual quality and new content. I could easily have never bought this and played it on an emulator for that purpose, but I chose to pay for this because I want classic games such as this to continue being ported. What I got instead was a heap of haphazard garbage that even an independent modder could have produced with more quality.

This is an instance of blatant disrespect not just towards the fans and customers, but to their own series. It is clear that there was little to no effort made in producing this port. Since initially it was a 'free' game for pre-ordering Tales of Zestria, why would they waste money improving it, right?

I hope that in the future, Steam will hold its clients accountable for such incredible lack of effort in porting games from console releases. There have already been the catastrophies that Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X's launches were, and now another highly significant port has been destroyed by nothing more than gross apathy from the title's owners.

In closing, this is unacceptable garbage. This would unacceptable even if I had received it for 'free' by pre-ordering Tales of Zestria, but asking for twenty dollars for this level of quality is insulting.

reviewText:
So let's count the number of problems the game had on release:

1. Massive save delay on Windows 7, fixed.
2. Massive Config menu delay, fixed.
3. 720p resolution regardless what you choose, fixed by a mod otherwise it gets blurry at high res.
4. Startup crashes. Assumed fixed as VMprotect was removed among other technical changes.
5. Different languages were a mess as there were typos introduced and languages were mixed up. Fixed.
6. Inconsistent button prompts (PS3 buttons in PC version). Fixed.
7. The most hated part of the port was VMprotect as it spat out a new temporary executable every time it launched, causing driver overrides to not work or obscured the game from being fixed easily. However before its removal it was mostly circumvented by a modder fixing the game. Its removal was silent but thankful.
8. Initially the port came with all of six save slots. I personally do not use that many but they have patched it to be 100 save slots. Anyone who has a gripe with only six can now rest easy.
9. Alt tabbing fullscreen used to take an average of 17 seconds or more or could even crash the game. This however has been patched.
10. The game is still 30 fps and is unlikely to be fixed. Author of Tsfix isn't going to fix it either.
11. Initially the game had even more quality issues such as the Zelos Badge being called a Mithos Badge as was the emoticon. I haven't stared at either since around launch but I have read that this inconsistency was fixed silently.

If Namco ever tries this again they can expect their sales to tank. They chose the cheapest option of porting Symphonia and the launch quality showed that. I imagine Berseria, the next game in the series, will be of higher quality as it is a new game and will not be subjected to zero quality assurance like this port of Symphonia received. They will most likely do preorders for Berseria as well so keep your eyes peeled for any tier" nonsense as if they offer another free Tales game do not assume it will be ported good.

Excuse me while I beat my face on my desk. I'm sure my desk can port my face into a new shape better than Namco did on this port.

I am including a mandatory article read:
http://www.pcgamer.com/broken-pc-ports-like-tales-of-symphonia-are-unacceptable/

I am changing this review to positive now since it's no longer a trainwreck and only because a certain modder was fixing the game up as well as the developers. I was reluctant to do so but the most major of issues has been fixed

reviewText:
One of the best JRPG games ever made, now on PC.

Tales of Symphonia is considered by many as the best game in the Tales of... series. And it's very easy to see why: the story is great, the characters are VERY memorable and well developed, the combat system is amazing... there's almost nothing wrong with this game. Sure, there are some chich√©s here and there, some cringe-worthy dialogues... but all that is easy to forgive when the game feels so special.

For the ones that don't know, the Tales of... games are a series of Japanese RPGs with big emphasis on character development and the storyline. The stories are full of fantasy, and usually blends drama and comedy in a fantastic and natural way. The game WILL make you laugh and cry throughout the journey, and nothing feels forced.

The combat system is not turn based, like most JRPGs. Instead, you control one character directly in an action based combat kinda similar to fighting games (but more simplistic). The other characters are controlled by the AI, and this AI can be configured to work like you want it to. Also, in battles, you can open the menu at any time and give orders to the secondary characters. As long as they aren't being attacked, they will obbey your orders. It's a very good system, since it keeps the strategy of most JRPGs, while being more dynamic than turn based combat.

This version of the game is based on the PS3 version, meaning we can choose between Japanese and English voiced, there are more skills and clothes, etc.

Yes, this is a great game. However...


-THE PC PORT:

The PC port is not very good. First of all, it's locked at 30 FPS. That may not bother everyone, so you are free to ignore this part of my review, but the fact is that this game should be 60 FPS. Heck, it was 60 FPS on the Gamecube! Also, it's locked at a 720p internal resolution, meaning the game will look pixelated. But you can use TSFix, an unnofficial fix created by Kaldaien, to make the game render at any desired resolution.

Lastly, the port seems to have quite a few stability issues for a few people. I got lucky, since the game is VERY stable in here, but some people are complaining about crashes, so I recommend that, if you buy it, you test it as soon as you can, before the refund window closes.


Anyway. I'm still recommending this game. Fact is, even though it's a weak PC port, the game itself is just amazing, and DESERVES a playthrough. And thanks to Kaldaien (creator of TSFix), we can use higher resolutions to make the game look better, among other things. You can even use MSAA to make the game look amazing at any resolution you choose. ^^

Review made february 25 2016.

Most of the problems that the initial release had have been fixed, I played this on day 1 and the problems were:

Crashes. The game used to crashfor some people, it crashed to me once on day one and it hasn't since.

The menus lag. Opening any menu and particularly the options menu had a delay af about 10 to 15 seconds for me, but people reported up to a minute or even more, THIS HAS BEEN FIXED.

Alt Tab problems. The game didn't alt tab  well, but you could do it if you are used to this kind of problem, now it works as it should.

The intro music is the japanese version. Not reallya problem for something everyone is going to skip most times but you can patch it if you really want the old opening.

Controls. I use a gamepad and have no issues with the controls, pushing ad pulling block works fine.

No 60 fps. The game runs at 30 fps and for this game is fine, it probably wont get fixed since this is a ps3 port.

In conclusion the game is good, f you played the Gamecube version and you want a widescreen port, this is the best one.

The original japanese voices sound way better than the english ones and that is what I value more of this game.

Important Information (March 18th): This review was made near the launch date. A good number of issues were addressed since then. I understand that people would consider this review not useful or inaccurate. And nope, I haven't finished the steam version yet. Thanks for your understanding.

Update (February 3rd): The Steam Overlay crash and the delays in Custom and Save for W7 users are fixed, the most important issues for me. I'll remove this negative review when I finish the story of the game.

Tales of Symphonia is one of the best games that I ever played on Nintendo GameCube.

I had illusion to play this game again in Steam and revive those charming moments with the story and their characters, but finding the shift+tab (Steam Overlay) crashing the game without even choosing New Game is devastating already.

I've read the other reviews too: a DRM that does who-knows-what, inexplicable delays for Windows 7 users (yes, I've experimented that already while picking Custom in the title menu), and even some videogame online magazines have categorized this port as broken. And I've only mentioned 2 or 3 issues of many.

I'm grateful that I got this masterpiece for free when prepurchasing Zestiria, but those serious issues that most people describe doesn't make the game worth 20‚Ç¨ / 20$.

I can't recommend this game right now due to the described issues. The game itself is awesome, I know because of my memories, but this port in its current state just breaks my nostalgia and my mood to play this game.

When I finish the story (40 to 50 hours), I'll remove this negative review or change it to a positive review.

reviewText:
Huge fan of this game, it's been one of my favorites ever since it came out back on the Gamecube when I was a kid. Hearing it would be coming to Steam featuring the content included in the PS2/PS3 rerelease was exciting news. I adore this game, and I'm still going to play it even though it needs some serious patching.

But in its current state, I can't recommend it to anyone quite yet. I'd love to change the review to something more positive once some of the most glaring issues have been addressed, many of which have been mentioned by other reviewers:

The game is prone to freezing and/or crashing when you try and select the customization/options menu in both the title screen and in-game. Every time I've attempted going into it, the game immediately locks up. Not good.
I thought I would be able to live with the 30 fps, but it looks ugly as sin, and the difference between this version and the original Gamecube version's framerate is extremely jarring. It doesn't look too bad in some areas, but the delays it causes in the battle system (which is a huge part of the game) are frustrating.
There's a bunch of typos I don't recall being in the Gamecube release. I've played that version 20+ times and originally I thought they had just copy/pasted the original English text, but there's typos and grammatical errors in this version I am positive weren't in the original English release.
A minor issue, but the soundfont for the soundtrack seems significantly different between this version and the Gamecube version. Can't decide if this is a pro or a con.
Please fix the crashing issues especially, Bandai Namco, and please take into account what people are saying about this game's port. A lot of people, myself included, are huge fans of this game, love it dearly, and only want the best for it so both old and new fans have better access to it from the start.

reviewText: Not the best port, but Durante's fix helps solve the most crippling issues with resolution, character outlines and stuttering. The 30FPS lock seems to be an unfixable issue, but considering this is a straight port from the PS3 (which in turn is a port from the PS2), it kinda sucks that they couldn't take that cap off. This is PC gaming, Namco. You don't have to cheap out by making a straight console port and changing almost nothing. The GameCube ran this game better 13 years ago, but it's still playable at 30FPS, albeit nowhere near as crisp as the GCN release. At the end of the day, this is still Tales of Symphonia, and it's a fantastic game in a beloved and underrated series that everyone should play. But if you can, try to get this game at a reduced price- the GameCube original is still somewhat reasonably priced these days, and $20 for this port just seems too steep for such a cheap port.

reviewText:
I originally put up a negative review on February 2nd because the DRM they added made it impossible for me to open the game.  A patch was released later on that day seems to have fixed the issues I was having and Symphonia is back in business. (The DRM is still there but it's no longer interfering with gameplay in any discernable way; I sent an e-mail to them requesting for help about 10 minutes before they released they patch and received a response earlier this morning).

tl;dr: Symphonia's port was a broken messed when released on February 1st, but any issue that the game was having was fixed within a day for me.

Unfortunately, the eyes still look low-res like they did in the PS3 version and it's really weird during close-up shots because the rest of the characters look so much sharper.

Symphonia's age is starting to show though.  When the game was released in 2004, the 3D battling system was groundbreaking.  But they've perfected it in newer games and the absence of certain features can make going back to this extremely weird.

The good news is that there is more content in this version than the original GCN version: 5/9's of the cast's mystic artes were dropped on the original but are present here, there's some new dialogue in places, some new titles and costumes, and such.

The story and the characters hold up well, and the first act of the game tease of cliche-storms and foreshadowing still makes me wonder how I missed it all as a kid.

The PC port has been updated to work with a standard keyboard and...I'm surprised to say it doesn't feel that weird. I thought I would be reeling a lot more from the control change but it's been honestly super easy to control and do what I want within the game engine so far (through Triet).

My only issue with the game is that there is no native support for a PS3 controller, but that's more of an issue with Windows than Tales.

reviewText:
Normally, I would start a review with my conclusive thoughts in a less blunt manner. However, I'm sure people won't bother read further if I don't mention the port.

It's another one of many Tales of Phon(ing)-in-a-game:
30 FPS lock from the PS3 version.
Internal resolution of 720p.
VMProtect software DRM, an anti-piracy software. I've read how it's both harmful to the PC as well as how it's not a big deal except for modders.
I don't think PC gamers are entitled for expecting more, but here's the thing: The game is playable. (I did have one or two issues around the 40 hour mark, missing voice-acting and one unexplained crash.)

All of this is to say I'm more focused on the merits and the problems about the game than its technical details. (They are problems, but none I would think as damning).

If those problems are issues to you, then you should voice your opinion with your wallet.

EDIT: I revised my review to focus more on the game's issues. I moved the block of text of nitpicks to the comments' section.

Enough Talk! Have at You!"
ToS's core gameplay focuses around its active-time battle-system which can be played with 1 - 4 players. (Or 0 if you want to play it like a traditional JRPG similar to FF13.)

This game doesn't require you to have friends (local) to enjoy it as the AI is "bearable" with minor baby-sitting. Nor does every character seem tailored for players. However
date: the novelty of playing a cooperative JRPG of 45 to 50 hours is what makes the feature stand out.\n\nAs for the gameplay
hoursPlayed: though too simple when you look for depth.\n\nIn spite of the variety of 256 enemies--with a lot of color-palatte swaps--and nine heroes
voteText: it's becomes obvious how there are only three enemy types for the whole game: Sorcerers/casters
helpfulPercent: melee fighters and rangers. (No hero acts like the last type.) Bosses also all fall within these categories
votesHelpful:
which makes them feel easier than cheaper enemies like mimics.

Simple enemy behaviors are not what makes the combat too simple. It's actually the battle-system itself.

Every engagement becomes a giant mosh-pit. You cannot move freely in battle--you can move forward and back
votesTotal: and change the camera if there is more than one enemy. The 2D movement results in every engagement converging to the center
votesFunny: which makes the tactics feel pointless. A simple fix would be to use the shoulder buttons to strafe around enemies.\n\nThe system also presents the problem when you get backed into a corner by the camera. You have no control over it
commentsCount:
which means enemies can obscure your character if there is only one enemy on screen.

All these issues do not take away from the visceral combat--if you stick with the melee fighters. Their move-sets are the best because they have the most fluid combat and they have the best combo potential.

It's not a surprise to me now that when my stepbrother and I played this game we always stuck with Lloyd

reviewText:
This is likely one of the best RPG games a person can play on a screen. While some people might not compare it to today's art and animation, this game will blow almost any modern game out of the water for story content. When compared to other modern games, it feels like the creators focused on the story first rather than last. Not to say the game has bad art or system controls, quite the opposite really. From the fight system to the world map the game comfortable and the controls for moving, fighting, and navigating the menus is too simple not to grasp. The characters don't look as blocky as some might expect, and capture the actual character's design beautifully. The in menu art is simply amazing, not much else to be said about it.

The game has great art, great story, and great form, and will make an excellent addition to any story lover's library. Any person who loves story will love this game, as this isn't some game you'll beat in a day of playing. Even knowing where everything was and ignoring the optional content, it took me nearly 38 hours to beat the game. Going through the game looking for all that extra stuff, completing all the things you can, this game can extend well over 150 hours.

While true that the New PC version has a few issues, they are easily fixed. For those who find it crashing on start up, simply run the game as the administrator and you're home free!

This is a treasure, and it brings me great joy to see it brought back.

reviewText:
Tales of Symphonia is one of my favorite games of all time. I played, and loved, the Gamecube original, I played Dawn of the New World and liked it, and I even spent the cash to get the collector's edition of the Chronicles rerelease. I absolutely love this game.

That said, it's with a broken heart that I can't recommend it.

You've all heard the old song and dance, all the problems that the game has:

The 30 FPS lock carried from the PS2 update
Crashing issues on certain systems
An internal resolution lock to 720p (which Durante, thankfully, fixed)
input lag that even I can notice (and I'm terrible at noticing it unless it's a full second delay)
Windows 7 users having a 30 second delay when saving
and, to add salt to the wound, a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• anti-tamper DRM that makes fixing it all the harder (and was bypassed almost instantly), as well as traces of Denuvo and SecuROM
If you must buy the game, don't spend any more than $5 on it.

Lloyd and the gang don't deserve this pile of crap of a port.

reviewText:
I remember spending hundreds of hours playing this game on the Gamecube, and was excited to see a PC port of it. I waited to get it, though, after seeing the flood of feedback on poor framerates and other issues, but when I finally caved in to my desire to relive my memories, I was thrilled to see that the game ran smoothly AND had the option for Japanese voice-overs, something that was sorely absent from the GC version.

However, I've barely made any progress at all, due to opting to start off on Hard Mode, and thus needed to grind a bit to both gain much needed strength and to regain my skills with Lloyd. That said, I've just managed to get Kratos in my party, and now have the Sorcerer's Ring... but I've discovered one MAJOR FLAW that will make this game almost unplayable for me once I make further progress...

WHERE THE ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• IS MY FREE-RUN?!? THAT IS A CRUCIAL PART OF THE BATTLES!!

Seriously! Without the free-run (I discovered the lack of it while fighting the Golems during the puzzle to get the Ring), there is only one way to fight any large monster or boss... running face-first into them - which, as we all know, is a Total Wipe waiting to happen at worst, and suicidally recovery-item-dependent at best. No free-run means having to COMPLETELY change how I play!!

That said, I'm still gonna play the game, but this NEEDS TO BE FIXED!! And the fix is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•in' simple! Change the default input on the gamepad (I use a usb-wired 360 controller) to the D-pad and put the free-run on the left bumper!

Despite this painfully suicidal issue, I still love it, and that love will never be diminished... or extinguished. And I would still recommend it, as it's one of the three games I'd ever consider doing a 100% Completion run of... the others being its sequel, Dawn of the New World, and Skies of Arcadia: Legends (which needs to be ported properly to Steam as well).

reviewText:
Tales of Symphona was one of the best JRPG's of the 4th generation of game consoles but is this port as good as it's Gamecube counterpart?

As of right now no it isn't, but it may still be worth your time.

PROS
-Active Combat Battle System
-Fun & Unique Characters
-Vast open world to explore
-Very good story & dialog
-Multiple Endings
-80+ hours of content

CONS
-30FPS Lock
-Delay in menus for Win7 Machines
-Intro Song is baaaad (mod available)
-Poor Texture Quality
-DRM is hidden in the game (WHY!?)

STORY

I'll keep it brief & spoiler free.  You play as Lloyd, a young warrior who's bad at school.  One day, you & your friends are in school as usual when a bright flash of light happens outside!  It's the signal that the chosen one, Collette, is ready to partake in her trials.  And then you set out on your adventure to bring Collette to the seals around the globe & awaken her as the Chosen One!  Eventually you learn being the chosen isn't what it seems & has a dark twist of fate.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is simple but also involves some strategy.  You move around the overworld as you would in any other JRPG while random encounters spawn in the world around you.  You can try to avoid them or run into one to start a battle.  Battles are fought on 2.5D plains where you control the main character (or later on the character of your choosing) & combine joystick movements with button combinations to do combos as well as blocking attacks.  You can also press the menu button & cast specific spells or use items.  Combining certain techniques & spells will unleash a super move that deals extra damage & usually has some sort of short cutscene attatched.  The real strategy comes from figuring out all the comboes & super techs & using them accordingly.  There are also block puzzles scattered throughout the dungeons that are usually required to progress.  Of course, there are also recovery items that restore health & magic points as well as equipment upgrades & all the stuff you would normally find in any RPG.

GRAPHICS

The graphics are pretty poor, but still look relatively nice considering the games age.  Obviously, due to the cell shaded art style.  Still, the textures are pretty poor all things considered.  This isn't an HD port, it's just a port.  Even so, you'd think they could have made it look a little nicer.  Everything is really pixelated.

The game is also locked to 720p resolution.  You can change the settings to go higher but it just upscales 720p to whatever you put it at.  The game honestly looks better at the default resolution because of this.  There's also a lack of graphics customization outside of the resolution which isn't very good either.

TECHNICAL ISSUES

The game runs at a locked 30FPS which is also a pretty big deal if you've played it running at 60 on the gamecube or other versions.  The active combat system feels like it was designed specifically for 60fps so you may have problems playing the game on higher difficulties.

If you're running on a Win7 machine you will probably experience some menu lag when trying to save or change the config settings.  A good 20-30 seconds of delay.  The devs have stated they are working on a fix for this issue.  Hopefully it will be settled soon.

AUDIO

The audio is actually one of the things that have been improved.  All the soundtracks & dialog are not compressed like the gamecube counterpart.  I haven't played the game on PS2/PS3 so I can't really compare that one.  It all sounds pretty good overall.  Excluding the J-Pop intro song, which just ruined the overall experience for me in the beginning.  Luckily someone released a mod that fixes it & replaces the music with the one from the gamecube.

The dialog is still as good as I remember it.  Being slightly cheesy & heartwarming while at times having that serious undertone for the moments that require it.  Voice acting in general is done very well.  I recommend playing this game with English voice overs just because the protagonist's voice actor is the same person who voices Robin from Teen Titans which was one of my favorite cartoons at the time this game came out.  All of the western voice actors sound great, imo.

After looking into the game more & trying to use game capture software to record some play sessions I was having some issues & I went to find out why on the good old interwebs.  This game has some heavy DRM hidden inside of it.  UNACCEPTABLE!  This game is over a decade old & does not need any DRM hidden in it!

OVERALL

I was really disappointed at first with the intro song debacle & the fact that I run a Win7 machine & the game will constantly have delays on Win7 while loading certain menu screens.  The devs have stated they are working to fix this issue, though.  The game itself remains intact, albeit at 30fps which is another large issue.  The gamecube version ran at a smooth 60fps so this feels like a downgrade & you can really feel the difference during combat & cutscenes. I can only recommend the game to people who have yet to actually play Tales of Symphona & who want to try it or for those who really just want to own the game again on PC.  As of right now, you should just wait for a patch & hope some of the issues are fixed especially if you're running on Win7.

reviewText:
I think this game is a prime example of a case where if people didn't know the game specs and just played it, then it would be an enjoyable experience.  Instead we know what the specs are (or rather are not) and that's colouring people's perspectives.  Yes it's locked at 30fps instead of 60 (which, I'm not endorsing and is a shame) and some people have had resolution issues (I personally have not but I know how frustrating it is when you can't adjust this setting).

But, specs aside, the game plays fine on my laptop and it's really fun.  I never played the original version so I can't compare but I do have Tales of Zestiria on Steam and Symphonia is a much more enjoyable experience.  The combat is quick paced and fun, the story is cheesy (a good thing when playing Tales games, imo), music is good and graphically the game looks great.  I've only played for 3 hours, but no bugs or crashes yet so that's a plus too.  The only downside about that actual game for me is the voice acting - the person who voices Lloyd also did Max from Dark Cloud 2 and it's a jarring enough disconnect for me that I actually turned them off (but that's just a personal issue, the voice acting itself is okay).

Bottom line, if you care about the specs then be aware that this is locked at 30fps.  If that doesn't matter to you then the game itself is pretty solid port of a great game.

reviewText:
Where to start...
I still have the game on GameCube and that is thoroughly one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've had in my 23+ year career as a gamer.  With that in mind, you can easily tell how hyped I was when I heard about this coming on PC and for 20‚Ç¨ no less!

The hype is hype, though.  While the game functions well enough (haven't gotten through the first dungeon yet, though) in that it starts, runs and functions well enough, I can see why people are callign this a disastrous port.  There are significant instabilities that CAN be avoided, if you know what they are.
For instance, the game crashes for me when I enter the configuration menu from the start menu (logical first step with any new game) and the loading times for save menus is abhorent *by modern standards.*  The config menu does work while in the actual game, it just takes nearly a minute to get in.
I can accept that this game is a port of a previous gen port, especially since I've never owned any other console than what Nintendo's produced.  I like the additional motion in the skits, I look forward to the added Anime cutscenes (which I know are in the PS3 version), I love that the redone japanese intro is in the game and I especially like the option of playing the game with japanese voice work.  That last one breathes new life into a game I've already played through multiple times with 40-80h on each playthrough (damn metal spheres...).  Best of all, I can play this game with an XB controller.

To address what people are really complaining about with this port are the graphics, the instability and the DRM.
I've been a gamer for over two decades, well into my prime for 16.  Graphics are something I don't particularly care about.  As long as it looks good, I like it.  That's why I grind through multiple classic games and occasionally revisit my Nintendo library.  Then again, 1080p is better than 720p, but that's more like a bonus to me than anything.
The instability is a big minus, especially since my antivirus detects each .tmp file the game creates when I try to change the settings before going into the campaign, promptly leading to an irresponsiveness crash.
The DRM....  When will devs learn that DRM doesn't do jack squat?

So to sum up my feelings about this port....  It has problems.  Boy, does it have problems, but it works.  And as long as it works, I'm willing to bend around them.  And since it works to my satisfaction, I give it a thumbs up.  A 51/49 thumbs up, but still.

Tl;dr I recommend this game for those who want a classic JRPG experience and are willing to forgive technical issues, especially those who want to ride on GC nostalgia.  If you're a graphics junkie who wants something modern and without technical issues, you might want to think twice before buying this.  And even then you better have a controller, since this thing is NOT meant for keyboard+mouse.  PS3 port owners shouldn't bother.


===POST UPDATE===
Lot of instability fixed, menus work well; still getting annoying F-secure popups about the .tmp files, though.

reviewText:
Game Score: 5.5/10

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Summery:

Tales of Symphonia arguably one of the more memorable J-RPGs on the Gamecube sadly just feels rushed and unpolished on PC.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Out of many of the Gamecube titles in it's library there are plenty of stand out titles outside of the usual Nintendo dispute being behind the PS2 and Xbox consoles. These games range from the Resident Evil Remake and Resident Evil 4, Star Wars Rouge Squadron II and Eternal Darkness just to name a few. While the system wasn't really the place for J-RPGs it arguably got one of if not one of the most memorable games of the past decade and longtime fans still consider it to be one of the best games on the Gamecube next to Metroid Prime and the aforementioned Resident Evil 4. This game I'm talking about is Tales of Symphonia which made some J-RPG fans who were stuck with all the Final Fantasy games turn their heads in some way. Tales of Symphonia was known for it's amazing characters and story, great battle system and it's responsible for creating a loyal fanbase that helped spawn a sequel as well as a Japan only animation. It was later ported onto the PS2 and PS3 in which they added some new content put played rather horribly and that can also be said for it's PC port which is now available for download on Steam.

Before I get into how terrible and unoptimized the PC port of Tales of Symphonia is I should explain just the basics of what the game is and how it is played. The game follows the protagonist Lloyd Irving who journeys with his friend Colette Brunel who is the chosen who must save the world from both the loss of mana and also a group called Desians which are causing people to suffer. Throughout the game you get to witness several character moments and backstories which are really great and gives each of the game's characters plenty of depth. Lloyd Irving the game's main protagonist is surprisingly likeable, he believes in a world where everybody lives their lives equally. Colette is a humorous klutz who trips over in some unexpected events, but something good comes out of it while also taking a few conversions out the window when her stupidity is in play. Presea is an emotionless girl who has lost her time being controlled by the exsphere but once she regained her emotions her characteristics involving her voice and likeness in paw pads make her very enjoyable. The best out of the Symphonia cast is Kratos a wondering swordsman with secrets that can't be spoiled here, he fells guilt over the things he felt so weak to accomplish and he's every bit as heroic as Lloyd and also believing in his ideals. He's a calm and collected character and his english voice by Cam Clarke is well delivered. Like in these Tales games you can expect to have several plot twists that can surprise first time players and despite the long story development time the storyline in Tales of Symphonia is really enjoyable and it will feature moments that will leave players laughing or crying in tears. The series stable is the skit system in which many of the characters chat over the currant events that will unfold or just plain idle chats which can be hilarious while other times just emotional that you often feel sorry for their situations at times. Each of the characters are voiced in both English and Japanese allowing you hear the original tracks from the Japanese version.

Tales of Symphonia is an Action RPG which was very different from the turn based RPGs that were out at the time. The game is split between an overworld where you enter towns to rest, get better equipment and get clues to your next objective. The overworld and each of the dungeons has several monsters to fight which require you to touch them to start each fight making you decide how you want to handle your battles. There are puzzles to solve as well as a challenging boss encounter that appears at the end. As long as you do spend actual time grinding up experience points to make your party members stronger and upgrading their equipment you shouldn't find the game hard on the Normal Difficulty setting.

Tales of Symphonia's battles take place in real time rather then turn based in which four of your party members are taken into battle with each of them having their own abilities called Artes in which you chain together to create highly damaging combos. While you can play alone you can add extra controllers (if your PC has extra USB slots) to have other players join in the battles locally. Enemies have a strength and weakness mechanic where enemies are weak against certain elemental attacks which can make battles a lot easier once you learn their weaknesses and how the enemies behave in battle. Later on in the game you'll access to the Unison Attack which allows four of the characters to combine all their attacks to create a powerful attack if the right attacks are met and also like in the PlayStation versions you can also pull off a Mystic Arte which deals major damage but require conditions in order to pull them off. The battle controls is a little hard to go back to if you have played the more recent Tales of Zestiria and it's more note worthy if you are playing with an Xbox 360 controller. Regardless Symphonia's battles are merely a product of it's time and it pretty much shows how much the game has aged which the rest of it I will come back to.

The gameplay does add some character customization, there are unlockable titles and costumes which are unlocked through completing sidequests. Sidequests require you to talk to various NPCs which have to be done at the right time in the story or some will become unavailable if you progressed to far. You can cook up meals to restore your characters HP, TP and status effects which can be learned from Wonder Chefs found in towns aside from using recovery items. There is also a Ex-Skill system where you can equip Ex-Gems gives characters different abilities and the correct combinations will give characters Ex-Skills like improved guarding, higher chances of critical hits, chances of resurrection and so on. Like in other Tales games there is plenty of customization which allows you to experiment to your playstyle and this game really does reward the player in that regard.

Now that I have talked about the gameplay of Tales of Symphonia it's time to talk about what is wrong with the PC port of the game. Now to be fair for a 13 year old game that originally came out on the Gamecube it does look great but the issue is that the game's graphics and overall design is based entirely on the PlayStation releases of the game. I've noticed that the PC version of the game is not running at a high definition resolution and I have seen on the internet that the graphics are at 720p resolutions. It means that you'll see things like dull and pixilated textures on the environments, stiff animations and also plenty of character clipping. What's also bad about the graphics in this port is that the frame rate is locked to 30 and there is some mild stuttering and some reported that they can run the game at best 40 fps. Other problems with the game come from the incomplete and broken translations, various typos, PS3 and XBox 360 button icons being used, random crashes, only six save slots, saving and loading taking 30 seconds to occur when played in Windows 7 and this DRM program called VMProtect which creates a new .exe" file every time the game boots up.

To see my full review of Tales of Symphonia for the PC then use this link. http://www.gamespot.com/tales-of-symphonia/user-reviews/2200-12688171/"

reviewText:
This game is just too good to be rating it negatively.
Yes the port had some very glaring issues, but official patches already fixed the most glaring issues (especially the language ones), and then the user mods did the rest.
There seems to be a 60fps mod on its way as well, so honestly there's no way to keep giving this game thumbs down anymore. This is one of the better games in the Tales series, as well one of the most iconic JRPGs of its generation, and it still holds up to this day.
If you're into the genres, by all means this is the game for you. If you haven't tried any JRPGs before then this is a very good starting point. If you straight up hate JRPGs then I guess avoid this one: the story is very much fond of the genre's cliches, but the Tales of battle system made one of its biggest improvements in this titles, so action and fighting games fans might just feel right at home with its combo system (which admittedly requires you to invest some time and leveling up in order to get to the good parts of it).

I know many people who played this back in the day and are sitting this port out due to the technical issues. To them I say that now it's fine to step in and buy the game.

To those who have never played this before, I can only suggest to play it once on their own. And then play it over and over again  (perhaps following guides from the second time around), because there are many things to do here, even missables and all, and I always found this to be one of the most replayable games out there despite its length.
