reviewText:
It seems like I may be the odd one out but I've not run into any of the issues being reported. Game opens perfectly every time, no audio issues though with headphones you can tell the audio was recorded in 2003/2004, no save or menu delay, to tearing, no vsync issues (though I hate that it seems to be forced), no crashing at all. The alt-tabing isn't great but that seems to be the case for anything not running borderless windowed mode which I hope they include in a patch otherwise I'll have to find a way to force it. The FPS for me hits 30 consistantly.
The lack of options kind of sucks but it looks a bit better than the PS3 version and feels a lot smother. (compated both on the same monitor) The battle system is identical to the PS3 and again feels smoother. Its not 60fps smooth but its definitly playable and the lower FPS hasn't had a real impact on the feel of the battle system. If you've only played the gamecube there are none of the extra c-stick options for artes in battle. The anime cutscenes could be smoother but other than that technical wise its been a decent port for me not perfect but nowehre near the worst.

I'm running a non-oc'd FX-8120, 16gb RAM, a gtx 970 and a basic 7200rpm HDD on my desktop. Audio is set at 24bit 192Khz.

For those that don't know, the PS3 version is based of the Japan only PS2 release not the Game Cube which is where the bulk of the extra content comes from as well as the slightly increased dificulty.

Story wise still as great as it always was, got it for christmas when if first came out and have put in well over 1000 hours over the years. Most characters aren't static and grow and change throught the story and makes you actually care about the characters and what happens to them. The story sits between sterious and whimsical, having moments of both but neither becoming overbearing. Definitly one of my top two Tales games along with Vesperia.

*note* hours played isn't too accurate, I mostly play in offline mode and Steam doesn't record offline hours
*Edit* Running the newest Windows 10 public build and the latest Nvidia drivers

reviewText:
I only recently got the time to pick this game again due to demanding college hours. I have played the original version back in the GC era, the PS2 remake, and the PS3 rerelease, haveing recorded 26, 13, and 8 playthroughs of each game respectively.  I may not have experienced the bitter taste of the initial phases of this game that I've heard horror stories of.

Anyways, here's my review.

Some Pros:

The TSfix mod that I installed out of caution has made this game look very good. Certainly better looking than the PS3 version.

In my opinion, 30FPS isn't that much of a problem if it's stable which it is with TSfix. I bet you people who have monsterous PCs would want to say otherwise. I can't say the same. I use a 2010 pre-built PC with a low end graphics card. Stable 30FPS is all I can afford and I'm getting it with TSfix.

Dual Audio is a good feature this game has if you're very used to the English version of this game by now and would like to try something new. Zestiria was like this which I appreciated. The Japanese audio has an entirely different tone to it compared to the English audio.

Some Cons:

Audio voice clips might not play during some scenes. This is bothersome if it's a significant scene as it subtracts some of the emotional value.

Some grammatical issues but there's not many at this point.

Some bugs like you recieve a title but the message says you got a totally different title.

Might just be me, but I can't use my mouse whatsoever.

I love Symphonia. It was one of the few games I had as a youngster and I didn't have many to play. It kept me entertained for years with it's interesting story, fun characters, and fun combat system. The game is also very long so don't expect to beat it in 2 days. While the port has had its downs, it's certainly playable as it is now.

reviewText:
I am not going to review the port (yes, it is not a good port, but bad reviews that discribe what is wrong with the port are all over the place) and I want this review to be for people who are interested in how the game itself holds up.

Tales of Symphonia is one of my favorite games of all time. I love every single party member and I always loved the art-style.
At first, the story and cast might seem cheesy and childlike, but the story is full of suprises and dark turns. All characters have depth to them which you will unfold during the story, and you will grow to care for every single one of them allong the way.
This game has several antagonists with also great designs. Some are not as strong depth wise as others but that will be because they play a lesser part.
Combat is super fun, I like cooking and item tweaking in this game.

The world is big, there are tons of hidden events, the story is long, but interesting enough to not lose interest, I like the English VA, even if they added the Japanese ones. And it has good replay and collectors value due to  NEW GAME PLUS, where you use GRADE(something you get after battles) to buy EXP bonusses, the saving of your gathered cooking recipes and more!

PLUS unlike the NEW Tales of games you can unlock tons of cool outfits through events in game (which are all lovely done and light-hearted between the dark aspects of the game) instead of having to BUY them.

All in all this is a very lovable RPG which only downside now is the fact that it is a port. So I recommend the game, and the port is not unplayable, but it's lacking.

reviewText: Tales of Symphonia may take some time to get a decent story started, but the gameplay and strategy more than make up for that common nitpick. This game is an example that should be shown to anyone designing a three dimensional competative fighting game, though you don't need to be an e-sports enthusiast to appreciate and enjoy this fun and replayable action RPG. It's a shame that cutscenes happen before a number of challenging bosses, but if you fight all random encounters that you run into, you will likely be about the right level for the bosses, so good play will reward you with little to no grinding. What this rerelease is really missing is the ability to play alongside friends via internet, but alas, we are restricted to local multiplayer and singleplayer play. Recomended more for the gameplay than the plot or characters, but all aspects of Tales of Symphonia can be enjoyed.

reviewText:
First off, they did announce W7 users may have issues with the game but a fix is in the works. The game IS also locked to 30FPS, seeing as it's a port of the PS3 version.

I've honestly had 0 issues with the game so far. Set it to 1080p res, windowed in the settings, had no delay or freezing. Set it to borderless via launch options. Granted it is 720p upscaled to a 1080p window, but the point is it's not causing the game to freak out like some are saying. Works fine for me.

I've had ZERO choppiness or anything while on the world map, in battles, transitioning between menus and saving. Everything has been buttery smooth for me while livestreaming at the same time. And yes this is from someone who regularly games at over 60FPS. Regardless, there will be a 60FPS fix soon enough just like there was for Zestiria so no need to be butthurt over it.


For free(for those that pre-ordered Zestiria) and $20 for others? It's really a drop in the bucket and worth it.
The game is as fun as I remember, I love it to death and I'll be sinking many hours into this baby.
It's by far my favorite 'Tales of' game and it's honestly well deserved in my personal opinion.  I hope others can enjoy it as much as many of us did in the past! I already ran into many people that never had the chance to play it previously and are now looking to get it. :) Definitely a great oppurtunity

reviewText: I spent over 2k hours on this game on the gamecube. That being said this port is just that. a port of an old game.  It's based on the ps3 version not the gamecube version which has more features but still no voice acting for the skits(the biggest flaw this game has. I played a few battles and ran around and did the intro mission and it seemed to be the exact same experience I had before, which is one of the best games I've played.  The game takes about 80 hours to complete the first time around, all of the reviews say 40-60 hours but if you are actually playing the game like a reasonable person without using guides and trying to get all of the titles, skills, identify all of the enemies, get all the obilisk, end game summons, items, and skits then no it will take you longer. There are things you can't get without beating the game 3 times minimum, which means to get everything you have to plan out your playthoughs meticulously to be able to get everything in three runs, worth mentioning if you want to do that kind of thing. There is an affinity level with the characters that affects cutscenes and changes key plot points(characters living or dying!).  There are events you will easily miss out on entirely on which provide significant character development.  After 1k hours, I was still finding new paths and cutscenes in this game. By intentionally going the direction I wasn't supposed to which in one or two instances did pay off and rewards you with seeing areas before they are destroyed and getting altered scenes and dialogue.\nIt's a great game with a ton of depth, character development and a story you can get behind.

reviewText:
This game is something I can not recommend enough to everyone to play through at least once. However - at the same time, I must take a moment to give words of caution. If 1080p and 60 FPS are huge selling points for you, this game might not be for you. And, unfortunately, due to a poor system in the port, the game is unplayable with certain OS's. Do research first and make sure you can play the game before buying - buyer beware on this.

However, I do think that this is a great game for those it works for. I happen to be one of the ones who had no issue running this, so my experience was only positive. I loved getting to revisit the lands of Sylvarant and Tethe'alla. The game is exactly how I remembered it, for all the good and bad.

The fight system is its strongest point. The LMB (Linear Motion Battle System) is just as great as ever, and the lack of free run, while confiding, is something you become accustomed to very quickly. I've missed this system, compared to more recent tales systems.

The story is still as corney, cringe-worthy cheese as it ever was. At the end of the game, you feel yourself rolling your eyes a little at just how cheesy the story is.

But that's part of the charm of the game, isn't it?

The graphics are still enjoyable, though - I will say, it feels like a slight downgrade from the original. There are some jagged issues around characters that I get on my system, and I am not sure if it's a port of personal setting issue.

Soundwise, the MUSIC of tales of symphonia is as amazing as it ever was. Fatalize still gives me that pumped up feeling it always gave me when I was a kid. The angelic themes for some fights still make me feel as though I'm fighting an insurmountable foe - whcih makes it all the more sweet when I beat them.

So. Overall. I can recommend the game - but do your homework. Ask yourself. Do you care about 1080p/60fps, or do you care if the game is good? And, can your system run it? Do not be afraid to refund if it cannot. Ignore the naysayers and decide for yourself.

reviewText:
I remember playing this game when it first released for the GameCube, and boy did I waste 200+ hours in it. Time to repeat that 200.

+Good ol cel-shaded goodness
+Characters are pretty interesting
+Story isn't dragged in the beginning, puts players into action after a small amount of detail
+Combat is fast and fun, especially for racking up combos
+Controller support covers most popular controllers, though I'm a keyboard kind of guy

-Since it's based off of the PS3 version, it's capped at 30 fps (though I'm sure that someone is/will be making something for it as they did for Tales of Zestiria)

+/- Game is decent looking, being the parent resolution being 720p and the changes are definitely noticeable when I changed to 1080. There are also no AA settings, so if you do set it to 1920x1080, there'll be a nice distinctive jagged edge every now and then that'll catch your eye for a second or two.

In overall, I'd definitely recommend this port despite the FPS and resolution downscale, for the storyline, characters, and battle system heavily outweigh them.

reviewText:
I bought the game out of nostalgia.

The game itself is as great as I remembered, but before the patching it was a messy port. The game is now patched and works fine. There are still some concerns:

The English dialogs audio does not play during cutscenes etc. Only the Japanese dialog works, but I bought this game for the nostalgia. So I don't mind Japanese since I watch anime's, but I wanted to enjoy the dubbed voice-overs. So again it ruins the nostalgia for me.

You can change the resolution to 1080x1920 in the customization menu, but the Internal resolution locked to 720p regardless of resolution.

The game is locked on 30fps and on the Gamecube it could go up to 60fps. But even on the Gamecube it did not run smooth on 60fps, but now the combat feels really sluggish. So I know this is the PS3 port, but still a fps lock on the PC makes no sense.

Do I recommend this game?
So I will recommend the game because of the nostalgia and the gameplay itself is fine, but these are issues need to be fixed in order to be considered a good/decent pc port.

reviewText:
(If you're looking for a PC port with a ton of optimization and customization, this unfortunately isn't for you)

Tales of Symphonia is still a game I recommend to people to get them started in the Tales series. It's one of the series' defining games. It's incredibly fun to play, and the story is engaging right from the start.

That being said, it's by no means perfect. It lacks a lot of features that make later games even better. Despite the battles taking place on a 3D plane, there's no free movement, as you're restricted to an X axis between you and the enemy you're targeting. The story, while it's pretty good, isn't as polished as a lot of the other series' games. It's also packed with plot twists, almost to a fault. The game in general just really shows its age. It's a dated game. But it's still an essential part of the Tales series.

tl;dr if you can't stand games made over a decade ago then don't play

reviewText:
This game is where my email and early Internet nicknames come from.  I've been playing it at least once a year since it came out in 2003, and tried out every single port of it (all uhh, two of 'em).  This is a port of the PS3 version which was itself inspired from the Japan-exclusive PS2 version.  More titles, more skits, more events, more bosses and harder enemies in general on harder difficulties, making Mania an actual challenge (unless you have 10x exp).

Despite being a port of the PS3 version, it still manages to be superior and that for three reasons:

1. Sure the internal resolution is locked to 720p, but so was the PS3 version, and the original was 480p.  Plus, it can be resized and played on windowed mode.
2. It doesn't take ages to save and load the game... in fact, it's instant; I keep getting surprised and saving twice in a row by mistake.

Without a doubt the best version of the best Tales game, ignore the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• FPS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• littering both the store page and forums with absolute filth just because a 13 years old game doesn't support 4K and 60 FPS; the game is amazing and yet they manage to make it even better with every port they make.

UPDATE:  Seems that when you do rebind your keys, it doesn't register properly and prevents you from doing puzzles, so it's a good thing the default controls are good enough.
